name: Robotic Arm Temperature Monitor
description: Dashboard to monitor single robotic arm temperature sensor data in real-time.

current_prd.elevator_pitch: Our Robotic Arm Temperature Monitor provides real-time temperature data from a single sensor, ensuring operational safety and preventing potential failures. It offers a clear, intuitive dashboard for engineers and technicians to quickly assess the robotic arm's thermal status, minimizing downtime and maintenance costs.
current_prd.problem_statement: Engineers and technicians lack a dedicated, real-time monitoring solution for critical temperature data from individual robotic arm sensors, leading to potential overheating, unexpected failures, and costly downtime.
current_prd.solution: The Robotic Arm Temperature Monitor provides a user-friendly dashboard that displays real-time temperature data from a single sensor on a robotic arm. This allows engineers and technicians to proactively monitor the arm's thermal status, identify potential issues, and prevent failures, thereby improving operational efficiency and reducing maintenance costs.

key_features.feature_description: Displays the current temperature reading from the robotic arm sensor in real-time on a dashboard.
Connects to the robotic arm's temperature sensor to retrieve data.
Provides a user interface for viewing temperature data and system status.
Backend service to continuously poll and store temperature data from the sensor.
API for the dashboard to retrieve the latest temperature readings.
Ensures secure communication between the sensor, backend, and dashboard, including user authorization and authentication as a critical first-phase feature.
Monitors the health and performance of the data acquisition service and API.

steps: User opens the dashboard application.
Dashboard initiates a request to the Temperature Data API.
Temperature Data API retrieves the latest temperature reading from the Data Acquisition Service.
Data Acquisition Service reads the temperature from the robotic arm sensor.
Data Acquisition Service sends the temperature reading to the Temperature Data API.
Temperature Data API sends the temperature reading to the dashboard.
Dashboard displays the real-time temperature to the user.
Data Acquisition Service starts.
Data Acquisition Service establishes a connection to the robotic arm temperature sensor.
Data Acquisition Service continuously polls the sensor for temperature data.
Sensor provides temperature data.
Data Acquisition Service stores the received temperature data (e.g., in a temporary buffer or database).
Data Acquisition Service makes the latest temperature data available for the Temperature Data API.
Monitoring system periodically checks the status of the Data Acquisition Service and Temperature Data API.
Monitoring system collects logs and performance metrics from both services.
Monitoring system detects anomalies or errors (e.g., API response time spikes, sensor connection loss).
Monitoring system generates alerts for administrators/technical operations team.
Technical operations team investigates and resolves the issue.
User navigates to the login page.
User enters their credentials (username/email and password).
System authenticates the user's credentials.
System authorizes the user's access based on their role.
User is redirected to the appropriate dashboard or application area.

current_prd.success_metrics: 99% uptime for the monitoring dashboard. Temperature data refresh rate of less than 1 second. Accurate temperature readings within +/- 0.5 degrees Celsius. Reduction in robotic arm downtime due to thermal issues by 15% within 6 months of deployment.
current_prd.competitors: Generic SCADA systems, custom-built internal scripts, existing robotic arm manufacturer's basic monitoring tools.
current_prd.vision: To expand into a comprehensive predictive maintenance platform for robotic systems, integrating multiple sensor types, advanced analytics, and AI-driven anomaly detection to prevent failures across entire fleets of robotic arms.

target_audience.name: Robotics Engineers
target_audience.pain_points: Lack of dedicated monitoring solutions, manual temperature checks, unexpected robotic arm failures due to overheating, difficulty in pinpointing thermal issues.
target_audience.demographics: Ages 25-55, typically male, holds a degree in engineering or a related technical field, works in manufacturing, automation, or robotics.
target_audience.needs_and_goals: Accurate and real-time temperature data, early detection of thermal anomalies, reliable monitoring tools, ensuring robotic arm longevity and performance.

target_audience.name: Maintenance Technicians
target_audience.pain_points: Complex and disparate monitoring systems, difficulty in diagnosing thermal problems, reactive maintenance leading to higher costs, limited visibility into sensor data.
target_audience.demographics: Ages 30-60, male or female, responsible for maintaining industrial equipment, often has a technical diploma or certification.
target_audience.needs_and_goals: Simple and clear temperature readings, quick identification of potential issues, tools to assist in preventative maintenance, minimizing equipment downtime.

phasing.rationale: This phase establishes the fundamental end-to-end data flow from the robotic arm sensor to a basic dashboard display. It allows for a clear demonstration of the core functionality: acquiring real-time temperature data and presenting it to a user. This is a demo-able version of the product.
phasing.phase_name: Demo 1: Core Data Flow & Basic Display

phasing.rationale: Building upon the core data flow, this phase integrates critical security measures and robust system monitoring. These features are essential for ensuring the reliability, integrity, and operational health of the system, making it suitable for a beta launch to a limited set of users or internal stakeholders.

current_prd.design_principles:
Clarity: Present temperature data in an easily understandable and scannable format.
Real-time Focus: Prioritize the immediate display of current temperature readings.
Simplicity: Ensure a clean and uncluttered interface, minimizing cognitive load.
Reliability: Design for consistent and accurate data presentation, reflecting the critical nature of robotic arm monitoring.
Accessibility: Ensure the dashboard is usable by all target users, considering different technical proficiencies.

user_personas.name: Robotics Engineer (Alex)
user_personas.goals: Monitor robotic arm temperature in real-time, identify thermal anomalies, ensure operational safety, prevent unexpected failures, optimize maintenance schedules.
user_personas.pain_points: Lack of dedicated real-time monitoring, difficulty in correlating temperature data with performance, unexpected downtime due to overheating.
user_personas.preferred_device: Desktop workstation, tablet for on-site checks

steps.description: Opens the Robotic Arm Temperature Monitor dashboard.
Displays the current temperature reading from the robotic arm sensor.
Quickly assesses the temperature status and identifies any immediate concerns.
Updates the temperature display in real-time.
Continues monitoring or takes action if an anomaly is detected.

user_journeys.context: Robotics Engineer (Alex) needs to view real-time temperature data from the robotic arm.

current_prd.navigation_design: The application will feature a single, prominent dashboard view. Navigation will be minimal, primarily focusing on the real-time temperature display. No complex menus or sub-pages are anticipated for this initial version. A clear, intuitive layout will guide the user's eye directly to the temperature reading.

user_stories.title: View Real-time Robotic Arm Temperature

user_story.i_want: to view the current temperature reading from the robotic arm sensor in real-time
user_story.so_that: I can quickly assess its operational status and identify any immediate thermal concerns.

acceptance_criteria: The dashboard displays the current temperature reading from the robotic arm sensor.
The temperature display updates automatically and continuously (e.g., every 1-5 seconds).
The temperature reading is clearly visible and easy to understand.
The dashboard indicates if the sensor data is not available or stale.

user_stories.title: Reliable Sensor Data Acquisition

user_story.i_want: the data acquisition service to reliably connect to the robotic arm sensor and continuously collect temperature data
user_story.so_that: the dashboard always has up-to-date information for monitoring.

acceptance_criteria: The Data Acquisition Service successfully establishes a connection to the robotic arm temperature sensor upon startup.
The service continuously polls the sensor for temperature data at a defined interval.
The service handles temporary sensor connection losses gracefully and attempts to re-establish the connection.
The service makes the latest temperature data available for retrieval by the Temperature Data API.

user_stories.title: Secure Temperature Data API Access

user_story.i_want: to securely retrieve the latest temperature readings from the backend
user_story.so_that: I can display accurate and up-to-date information to the user.

acceptance_criteria: The Temperature Data API provides an endpoint for the dashboard to request the latest temperature reading.
The API responds with the current temperature data within an acceptable latency.
The API handles requests securely, ensuring only authorized access.
The API returns an appropriate error message if the data acquisition service is unavailable or returns no data.

user_stories.title: System Health Monitoring and Alerting

user_story.i_want: to be automatically alerted to issues with the data acquisition service or API
user_story.so_that: I can quickly identify and resolve problems, ensuring continuous temperature monitoring.

acceptance_criteria: The monitoring system periodically checks the health and performance of the Data Acquisition Service and Temperature Data API.
The system collects relevant logs and metrics (e.g., CPU usage, memory, API response times, sensor connection status).
The system generates alerts (e.g., email, SMS) to the technical operations team when critical thresholds are exceeded or errors occur.
The system provides a dashboard or interface for viewing service health and logs.

user_stories.title: Intuitive Temperature Dashboard Interface

user_story.i_want: a clear and intuitive dashboard interface
user_story.so_that: I can easily understand the robotic arm's temperature status at a glance and on my preferred device.

acceptance_criteria: The dashboard prominently displays the current temperature reading.
The dashboard interface is intuitive and easy to navigate.
The dashboard provides a clear visual indication of the temperature status (e.g., using color codes for normal, warning, critical ranges).
The dashboard is responsive and accessible on both desktop workstations and tablets.

user_stories.title: Secure System Access and Data Transmission

user_story.i_want: to ensure all components of the temperature monitoring system are secure and data transmission is encrypted
user_story.so_that: unauthorized access and data breaches are prevented, maintaining system integrity and compliance.

acceptance_criteria: The system requires proper authentication (e.g., API keys, tokens) for accessing the Temperature Data API.
All data transmission between the sensor, data acquisition service, API, and dashboard is encrypted (e.g., using TLS/SSL).
Access controls are in place to ensure only authorized users/systems can view or interact with the temperature data.
The system logs all access attempts and security-related events for auditing purposes.

user_stories.title: User Authentication and Authorization for Dashboard Access

user_story.i_want: to securely log in and access only the data I am authorized to view
user_story.so_that: I can monitor robotic arm temperatures with confidence in data security and privacy.

acceptance_criteria: Users can register for an account with a unique username and strong password.
Users can log in to the dashboard using their registered credentials.
The system verifies user credentials and grants access based on their roles.
Users are only able to view temperature data for robotic arms they are authorized to access.
Failed login attempts are logged and trigger appropriate security measures (e.g., account lockout after multiple failures).
The system provides a "forgot password" mechanism.

tasks: Test real-time updates, data accuracy, error messages
Monitor API performance for real-time data

systems_engineer: Monitor API performance for real-time data

tasks: Design and implement data acquisition service

backend_developer: Design and implement data acquisition service

tasks: Design and implement secure API endpoint

backend_developer: Design and implement secure API endpoint

ui_ux_designer: Design monitoring dashboard/interface for health and logs

story_point_table.user_story_title: Secure System Access and Data Transmission

tasks: Design user registration, login, forgot password, authorization views
Implement user registration, login forms, forgot password flow
Implement user authentication, authorization, password management
Test user registration, login, authorization, password reset, security measures
story_point_table.user_story_title: User Authentication and Authorization for Dashboard Access

current_prd.tam_description: Total Addressable Market for the Global Industrial Automation and Predictive Maintenance Market, encompassing all solutions for industrial control, robotics, and proactive equipment maintenance.
current_prd.tam_estimation_basis: Based on the combined market size of global industrial automation and predictive maintenance solutions, which includes hardware, software, and services for optimizing industrial operations and preventing equipment failures.
current_prd.tam_source: Hypothetical data based on industry reports for Industrial Automation Market (e.g., MarketsandMarkets, Grand View Research) and Predictive Maintenance Market (e.g., Statista, Allied Market Research) for 2023-2024.
current_prd.sam_description: Serviceable Available Market for Robotic Arm Monitoring and Basic Predictive Maintenance Solutions, representing the segment of the industrial automation market specifically focused on dedicated monitoring and early anomaly detection for robotic arms.
current_prd.sam_estimation_basis: Estimated as 15 percent of the TAM, focusing on the subset of industrial robotics requiring dedicated real-time temperature monitoring solutions beyond generic systems or basic manufacturer tools. This segment addresses the specific pain points of engineers and technicians regarding robotic arm thermal status.
current_prd.sam_source: Hypothetical data derived from TAM, considering the installed base of industrial robotic arms and the growing need for specialized monitoring solutions (e.g., IFR World Robotics Report, various industrial IoT reports).
current_prd.som_description: Serviceable Obtainable Market, representing the realistic market share a new Robotic Arm Temperature Monitor can capture within the Robotic Arm Monitoring and Basic Predictive Maintenance Solutions Market over a 5-year horizon.
current_prd.som_estimation_basis: Conservative 2.5 percent market share estimate over 5 years, considering the initial single-sensor focus, competitive landscape (generic SCADA, custom scripts), and the time required for market penetration and adoption of new industrial monitoring solutions.
current_prd.som_source: Competitive analysis of existing monitoring solutions, typical market entry success rates for specialized industrial software, and adoption curves for new technologies in manufacturing.
current_prd.pricing_model_basis: Subscription-based per robotic arm per month
key_competitors: Existing robotic arm manufacturer's basic monitoring tools
current_prd.advantage_summary: Dedicated real-time temperature monitoring from a single sensor, intuitive dashboard, proactive issue detection, minimizes downtime, reduces maintenance costs, user-friendly for engineers and technicians.

planned.model_content:
class TemperatureSensor < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :organization
  has_many :temperature_readings, dependent: :destroy

  validates :name, presence: true
  validates :location, presence: true

  rhino_owner :organization
  rhino_references [:organization]
end
planned.migration_content:
class CreateTemperatureSensors < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.2]
  def change
    create_table :temperature_sensors do |t|
      t.string :name, null: false
      t.string :location, null: false
      t.references :organization, null: false, foreign_key: true

      t.timestamps
    end
    add_index :temperature_sensors, :name, unique: true
  end
end
planned.rails_model_generation_command_line: rails generate model TemperatureSensor name:string location:string organization:references

planned.model_content:
class TemperatureReading < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :temperature_sensor

  validates :temperature, presence: true
  validates :recorded_at, presence: true

  rhino_owner :temperature_sensor
  rhino_references [:temperature_sensor]
end
planned.migration_content:
class CreateTemperatureReadings < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.2]
  def change
    create_table :temperature_readings do |t|
      t.float :temperature, null: false
      t.datetime :recorded_at, null: false
      t.references :temperature_sensor, null: false, foreign_key: true

      t.timestamps
    end
  end
end
planned.rails_model_generation_command_line: rails generate model TemperatureReading temperature:float recorded_at:datetime temperature_sensor:references
